details.keywords: weight, height, length, bmi, must, malnutrition universal screening tool

item.list: SNOMED-CT::443216009::Assessment using malnutrition universal screening tool

term_definitions.items: Additional composition metadata aligned with IHE-XDS which is not already available from the Reference Model COMPOSITION class.
The speciality of the author/composer of the document.
A high-level document class code, normally selected from a valueset provided by the IHE-XDS Affinity Domain.
For example: Report, Summary, Images, Plan, Patient Preferences, Workflow. These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
The code specifying the precise type of document from the user perspective. Normally selected from a valueset provided by the local IHE-XDS Affinity Domain or national standard.
for example: Pulmonary History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Ultrasound Report. These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
A term specifying the level of confidentiality of the XDS Document.
Coded text is preferred, normally specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
A term defining the healthcare facility type.
Coded text is preferred. The codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
The code specifying the clinical specialty where the act that resulted in the document was performed.
For example: Family Practice, Laboratory, Radiology. Coded text is preferred, normally specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
Additional metadata about the document itself, including size, url.
This list of codes represents the main clinical acts.
Unique identifier for each appointment process.
Unique identifier for each encounter process.
Type of encounter, should be provided by terminology server.
Reason for encounter, should be provided by terminology server.

Provides extra information about the encounter context, regarding the internal cases used at Pathfinder for encounter types and reasons, along with an appointment and encounter id. Terminology should be loaded from the Think!EHR terminology adapter.
Screening tool for malnourishment, undernutrition or obesity.
Default, unspecified point in time event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Derived from the subject’s body mass index.
To establish the subject’s weight loss score, ask if there has been any weight loss in the last 3 – 6 months, and if so how much (or look in their medical records).
Deduct current weight from previous weight to calculate amount of weight lost and calculate percentage. If the subject has not lost weight (or has gained weight) score 0.

If the subject is currently affected by an acute patho-physiological or psychological condition, and there has been no nutritional intake or likelihood of no intake for more than 5 days, they are likely to be at nutritional risk.
Such patients include those who are critically ill, those who have swallowing difficulties (e.g. after stroke), or head injuries or are undergoing gastrointestinal surgery.
Not acutely ill and sufficient nutritional intake for >5 days
If patient is not acutely ill and there has not been or is not likely to be no nutritional intake for >5 days.
Acutely ill and there has been or is likely to be no nutritional intake for >5 days
If patient is acutely ill and there has been or is likely to be no nutritional intake for >5 days.
The sum of scores for body mass index, weight loss and acute disease effect.
The overall risk of malnutrition as derived from the total score.
Total score equal or greater than 2.
Height determination method for body mass index
Method used for determining height as a part of body mass index calculation.
Weight determination method for body mass index
Method used for determining weight as a part of body mass index calculation.
Recently documented or self-reported height (if reliable and realistic).
Recently documented or self-reported weight (if reliable and realistic).
Method used for determining body mass index.
Calculation from height and weight measurements
Derived from mid upper arm circumference measurement
Method used for determining weight change.
Recently documented or self-reported weight change
Derived from changes in mid upper arm circumference measurement
Some variables used in the calculation of the MUST score may be influenced by confunding factors, specially in the case of weight and BMI determination.
Examples of confunding factors are fluid disturbances, lactation, pregnancy, critical illness and amputations. These and other situations deemed as confunding should be registered here.
Additional narrative about the screening, not captured in other fields.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Description of the state of dress of the person at the time of weighing.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight, including shoes.
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Wearing only a nappy - which may add significantly to weight.
Additional narrative about the measurement of Body weight, not captured in other fields.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body weight eg timing in menstrual cycle, timing of recent bowel motion or noting of amputation.
Usually the first weight, measured soon after birth. This event will only be used once per health record .
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot.
Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
Description of the device used to measure height or body length.
Height is measured standing on both feet with weight distributed evenly, heels together and both buttocks and heels in contact with a vertical back board.
Additional narrative about the measurement, not captured in other fields.
Narrative description of any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement.
Length is measured in a fully extended, recumbent position with the pelvis flat, legs extended and feet flexed.
Usually the first length measurement, recorded soon after birth. This event will only be used once per health record .
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Calculated measurement which compares a person's weight and height.
Body Mass Index is a calculated ratio describing how an individual's body weight relates to the weight that is regarded as normal, or desirable, for the individual's height.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Index describing ratio of weight to height.
The method of entering the body mass index.
Body Mass Index calculated and entered automatically without user intervention.
Body Mass Index calculated and entered directly by user.
Formula used to derive the body mass index.
Narrative description of any issues or factors that may impact on the calculation.
For example: the calculation was made using adjusted weight or height.
Additional narrative about the calculation, not captured in other fields.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the body mass index.
For example: underweight, normal, overweight or obese.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

item.list: Routine clinical care - Use nutrition care plan.
Observe - Refer to nutrition care plan for MUST 1.
Treat - Refer to nutrition care plan for MUST 2+ OR if patient is unable to eat and artificial nutrition (e.g. NG, PN) is appropriate, please refer immediately to Dietitian.

term_definitions.items: Measurement of the length, height or width between two identified points on the body.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the body segment measured.
The way the body segment is measured should be recorded using the 'Method' element and/or recording the 'Measurement origin' and 'Measurement endpoint'.
Measured value of the length of the body segment.
Additional narrative about the measurement of a body segment, not captured in other fields.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of the body segment.
An average of multiple measurements of the same body segment.
Details of the device used for measuring the body part.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Vertical distance between the sitting surface and the vertex of the head. A measure of trunk length, performed with the individual sitting erect.
Distance between the shoulder and the elbow.
Distance between the hip joint and the ankle joint.
Distance between the hip joint and the knee joint.
Distance between the base of the heel to the tip of the longest toe.
Distance between vertex of head to the lowest part of the trunk.
Distance between the sole of the foot and the top of the lower leg.
Distance from fingertip to fingertip with both arms fully extended at right angles to the body.
Narrative description of the method used for measurement.
Specify in order to ensure that a sequence of measurements are taken at the same point and in the same way. For example: 'Sitting with knee bent at 90 degrees'.
Identification of a simple body site for the location of the starting point of the measurement.
A structured anatomical location for the starting point of the measurement.
The position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Identification of a simple body site for the location of the ending point of the measurement.
A structured anatomical location for the endpoint of the measurement.
Standing at the time of measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of measurement.
Reclining at the time of measurement.
Lying flat at the time of measurement.
The difference between measurements of the same body segment measured from each side of the body.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Description of the state of dress of the person at the time of weighing.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight, including shoes.
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Wearing only a nappy - which may add significantly to weight.
Additional narrative about the measurement of Body weight, not captured in other fields.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body weight eg timing in menstrual cycle, timing of recent bowel motion or noting of amputation.
Usually the first weight, measured soon after birth. This event will only be used once per health record .
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight.
Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".
The date at which the absence was last updated.
Description of the reason why there is no information available.
For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

default_value.value: SNOMED-CT::443216009::Assessment using malnutrition universal screening tool
